<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_shmem_register_generic:
```c
int metal_shmem_register_generic(struct metal_generic_shmem *shmem)
{
	/* Make sure that we can be found. */
	metal_assert(shmem->name && strlen(shmem->name) != 0);

	/* Statically registered shmem regions cannot have a destructor. */
	metal_assert(!shmem->io.ops.close);

	metal_list_add_tail(&_metal.common.generic_shmem_list,
			    &shmem->node);
	return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function metal_shmem_register_generic:
struct metal_generic_shmem {
	const char		*name;
	struct metal_io_region	io;
	struct metal_list	node;
}
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
	metal_assert(shmem->name && strlen(shmem->name) != 0);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: Yes. strlen(shmem->name) is called after only checking shmem->name is non-NULL; there is no guarantee the pointed object is NUL-terminated or that a NUL byte exists before the end of the object. For example, if shmem->name = buf where char buf[3] = {'A','B','C'} (no terminating '\0'), strlen(shmem->name) will read past buf and may access out of bounds (undefined behavior). This can violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17.
